title: 113_hr2918
content: The Act titled "Coal Healthcare and Pensions Protection Act of 2013" includes provisions for certain retirees to be included in the multiemployer health benefit plan. Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for the calculation of excess beneficiaries enrolled in the Plan. Enrolled beneficiaries in the Plan eligible for health benefits under the Coal Healthcare and Pensions Protection Act of 2013, including those receiving benefits from an employer in the bituminous coal industry under a coal wage agreement. An individual eligible for health benefits under the Coal Healthcare and Pensions Protection Act of 2013, due to a bankruptcy proceeding in 2012, can receive benefits under the Plan. The transfer amount is calculated based on excess funds and any previous transfers from a voluntary employees' beneficiary association. The Coal Healthcare and Pensions Protection Act of 2013 allows individuals affected by a bankruptcy proceeding in 2012 to receive benefits under the Plan. The administrator of a voluntary employees' beneficiary association must transfer any funds received from the bankruptcy proceeding to the Plan, minus administrative costs. Additionally, if the dollar limitation exceeds the total amount, additional funds may be calculated. The Coal Healthcare and Pensions Protection Act of 2013 allows individuals affected by a bankruptcy proceeding in 2012 to receive benefits under the Plan. If the dollar limitation exceeds the total amount required to be transferred, the Secretary of the Treasury shall transfer additional funds to the trustees of the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan to pay benefits. The term '1974 UMWA Pension Plan' is defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RULE FOR CERTAIN SUPPLEMENTAL BENEFIT PLANS. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a special rule for certain supplemental benefit plans. Contributions made by an employer under a plan providing supplemental benefits solely to participants in a pension plan will not be deductible under this section but will be governed by section 162. The trust holding the assets of such a plan will be treated as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(a). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes a special rule for certain supplemental benefit plans. Contributions made by an employer to a plan providing supplemental benefits to participants in a pension plan will be treated as contributions to the plan, regardless of whether they are paid into a trust. Additionally, payments made by an employer to the trustees of the plan, and benefits paid by the trustees, will be considered contributions and benefits of the plan. This rule applies to exclude certain payments from wages for payroll taxes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has a special rule for supplemental benefit plans. Contributions by employers to such plans are treated as contributions to the plan, even if not paid into a trust. This rule excludes certain payments from wages for payroll taxes. Amendments have been made to various sections of the Code to include plans under section 404(p)(1). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has a special rule for supplemental benefit plans, with amendments made to include plans under section 404(p)(1). A new paragraph has been added to exclude payments made to individuals under such plans from wages for payroll taxes.
